thread.title: Stoke-on-Trent by-election: Narrowing gap on Labour is scant consolation for Ukip in 'Brexit capital of Britain'
thread.title_full: Stoke-on-Trent by-election: Narrowing gap on Labour is scant consolation for Ukip in 'Brexit capital of Britain'

author: Joe Shute
title: Stoke-on-Trent by-election: Narrowing gap on Labour is scant consolation for Ukip in 'Brexit capital of Britain'
text:
Joe Shute Stoke-on-Trent 24 February 2017 • 5:25am Ukip leader and candidate Paul Nuttal talks to the media after coming second in the Stoke-On-Trent Central by-election Credit: Getty Images 
P oor Gareth Snell. When the newly-minted Labour MP stood on the podium to deliver his winning speech after triumphing in the Stoke-on-Trent Central by-election, it was to face a sea of journalists – all with their backs turned. 
The cameras were only interested in the reaction of one man, perspiring and rictus-grinned in the crowd behind them. 
This was meant to be the night the Ukip leader Paul Nuttall trounced Labour and stormed triumphantly into Parliament on a wave of populist support. Labour's Gareth Snell, left, celebrates with the candidate for The Official Monster Raving Loony Party Credit: Getty Images 
I nstead, he found himself standing next to the leader of the Monster Raving Loony Party, Howling Lord Hope – who offered Nuttall the consolation that while he had now failed four times to become an MP, for the Loony man it was 22 and counting. 
As Nuttall pointed out afterwards, he had managed to cut the Labour majority in half. Snell, a son of the Potteries, received 7,853 votes to Ukip’s 5,233 . The Conservatives...
